dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on October 20, 2022
reviews: \nBiggest Upgrades/Changes from Echo Dot 4th Gen (2020) to Echo Dot 5th Gen (2022):-SPEAKER:  Now 1.73-inch speaker with improved bass/low end, previous version was 1.6-inch-TEMPERATURE/MOTION SENSORS:  Now with temperature and motion sensors Echo Dot can trigger routines based on detected motion or changes in room temperature.-EERO WIFI EXTENDER: Supports Eero \u201cBuilt-In\u201d, works as a WiFi extender for Eero mesh networks, supporting up to 10 additional devices and up to 100Mbps speeds.-ACCELEROMETER/TAP: Now can trigger actions with a tap, like stopping alarm-NO LINE OUT: Removed 3.5mm line out port from the back-WEIGHT: Now 10.7 oz, previous version was 12 oz-APPEARANCE: Very similar to previous version, but fabric looks slightly different (less shiny), now available in Charcoal, Glacier White and Deep Sea Blue; previous version was Charcoal, Glacier White and Twilight Blue.(Note - I STILL received a Glacier White 15W power adapter and cable, even with Black Echo Dot.  This was also the case with the previous version)The new Echo Dot 5 is visually very similar to the 4th gen version from 2020, but these are some nice functionality improvements.-The speakers have been upgraded, now with more focus on low end and bass volume.  I have tested out a few different types of music, and I would agree that there is noticeable improvement, but really the speaker is still too small to be very impressive.  The sound is not even close to a regular Echo device, let alone higher quality speakers.  I appreciate the improvement here, but I still wouldn\u2019t choose to listen to music on these on a regular basis, especially at high volume where there is a bit of distortion.-I like the ability to be able to trigger routines based on temperature and motion, and stopping alarms by tapping is also a nice feature.  These additions offer many more useful automation options, and now having multiple Echo devices with temperature sensors can help identify differences in room temperature throughout the house.-The Eero Wi-Fi extender ability could actually be very useful for some people that need to extend the range of their network.  This was easy to configure with the Eero app, and it seems to be working well so far.Overall, this is a nice little upgrade from the previous version.  The speaker/sound improvement is nice, but not the biggest deal since these Echo Dots are still not the best choice for high volume music.  The sensors and Eero extender features are the biggest improvements, and these changes add so much extra functionality to an already useful smart speaker.  The lack of an audio-out port is the only downgrade, but that might be important to some people.  I also wish they included different color power adapters and cables, but that is also not the biggest deal.  I will be grabbing a few of these new Dots, since the Eero Built-In will come in handy for certain places we need to extend coverage.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on November 27, 2022
titles: Even better than a prior versions
reviews: \nI started out with Amazon about 6 years ago. At some point, after "The A-Queen" pissed me off for the last time (we've all been there!), I made the move to the Google eco-system. And life was good for a long time. In the meantime, I watched Amazon continue to invest in new products and new features. But Google was doing what I wanted and I continued to invest in their hardware. However, at some point Google engineers decided that we all wanted to hear more from our smart devices. Commands that used to simply prompt a "ding" at some point became " Got it! Playing (artist) from your Google playlist on Kitchen Music". And when you simply wanted to pause or stop, it was the same thing: " Got it! Stopping music on Kitchen Music". So like if someone called on the phone while music was playing you had to wait till "G-Man" was done spouting off to answer. Or changing music during a party with voice command literally became embarrassing. Going online it turns out a lot of people complain about this and Google simply chooses to turn a deaf ear to these complaints. This year (2022) I decided to look at the new Echo eco-system. So for Black Friday I ordered the new Dot v5 to make the comparison. Well, much to my pleasure, Amozon has decided that less is more. When I ask Alexa to stop playing music I am met with a simple "ding!".  How refreshing! So... not looking good Google! At the same time my house is solar powered so I've bee changing my house over to electric heating (from oil). This presents a huge opportunity to employ smart home technology to conserve energy. Well, turns out Amazon has LEAPT out in front of Google in features. Temp sensors?! Motion detection?! Wow! And low and behold it all works! Actually, move beyond smart thermostats. Imagine filling your house with speakers and being able to create a new heating zone with each one. I use Lutron Caseta hardware. Their switches integrate perfectly with Alexa. Learn how to wire in a relay and voila! the possibilities are pretty extensive. Google is so far behind on this stuff, they're stuck in the "we can answer more questions" mode. Well, Hello Amazon! Sorry you lost $10 Billion dollars last year. I promise going forward I'll be helping you get some of it back (lol). And to Google: sorry you couldn't learn that less can be more. Your loss!\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on December 17, 2022
titles: Like it so far after setting it up and trying out the sound.
reviews: \nWas easier to set up than the generation 4 Dot. Sounds good, better than Dot 4. Nice to link them together to play music in multiple rooms at the same time. Dislike that the light keeps swirling and rotating during the night, so I have to unplug it every night. Wish I could have been able to turn it off but haven't figured it out yet. Wanted to use it to listen to nice music to go to sleep to or wake up to. Had some difficulties with getting it to work, but Amazon tech support was very good. Wish there would be a list of typed commands, because guessing them is not working for me. At times both dots need upgrades and they do not perform until you call someone and sit on the phone for an hour or so to upgrade it and get it reset. That's bad. It's happened at least four times in less than a year with Dot 4. Hopefully I don't have to keep calling them back to get it to respond. At times, having to repeat myself over and over different manners before it recognizes what it's supposed to do. It's because I can't get a typed list of appropriate commands from anyone. I am not a computer techie, And finally got my first smartphone a year ago,so it's frustrating. You have to have an app on your smartphone to set them up and make them work, or to change settings, alarms, etc. Again, wish there was some printed literature somewhere or even online but I have been told by Amazon techs there is nothing. With constantly changing technology, it seems like they would put something out. Love the idea that I can plug it in outside and play music instead of bringing my giant boombox outside in the summer. Looking forward to that.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on March 11, 2023
reviews: \nStandard for all my reviews: When reviewing products, I always remain objective and honest about the product or service. I review with information I feel others would like/need to know about the product as I assume my review may influence the purchase. I always try to go above and beyond surface characteristics and input into quality, value, and application. Most importantly, I end each review with an answer as to whether I'd purchase the product again which I believe is the most critical question pertaining to the item. To manufacturers: Want me to review your items, drop me a message!I resisted the temptation to add any smart home assistants like Alexa until the technology matured and came down in price. I'm glad I waited and I've just started setting up my smart home.I started with the 5th Gen Echo Dot and recently added a second to my upstairs office. Installation was a breeze and I filled out most of the needed information before it/they even arrived. By doing so, you can have it attach to your Wifi network as just after it powers-on for the first time.We've been having a lot of fun with them and I could see adding one more in the bedroom or our workout/zen room. We use it for morning news, music, general information, etc. Our favorite feature is probably the intercom which allows us to open up a conversation between floors so we can have a discussion without needing to go upstairs/downstairs all the time. The announcement features are fun as well, like announcing dinner is ready.As would be expected, additional power with Alexa is unlocked when you add your Alexa-capable devices attached. I also recently purchased smart light switches that can be controlled through Alexa to turn on/off the lights, set up activities/shedules, etc., in addition to adding some of my LED lights and my Nest thermostat.The speaker is upgraded in this generation and while I haven't tried the gen 4 or previous unity for comparison, the small built-in speaker has good tonality with a good balance of treble/bass, which can be adjusted. The sensitivity of the unit when you say "Alexa" is astoundingly good. A lot of little features built in you wouldn't know about if you didn't get the ongoing tips and tricks. We are finding new things you can do almost every day.The only criticism(s) I have is that I wish in came in different colors and that the power cords would match the unit itself. I purchase the black ones and they come with a white cord. It's fine ... after you get used to it.At the $50 price tag, it's easy to provide the interface in your home to pull all your smart devices together for control and for features to make your life easier or, at least, more efficient. I could see how adding other Alexa-aware smart devices could be addictive.I would purchase this product again without question, and already did in fact.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on March 14, 2023
titles: I waited long enough, finally made the move
reviews: \nI purchased this product so that I can listen to music, but will most likely use it for additional things in the future. It's a small device with big sound - great output! I renamed mine Ziggy and assigned a male voice for responses - personal preference. It plays for 4 hours before automatically turning off - will have to check to see if there is a setting to adjust this for a longer duration. A great buy for Prime members!\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on December 18, 2022
reviews: \nI\u2019ve had Echo Dots since they came out. Always been reasonable quality for their purpose; basic AI interaction and smart device control. The speakers have always been\u2026 okay. You had to go to a larger Echo device or link to a Bluetooth speaker to get reasonably good sound for music. While this device isn\u2019t going to replace your home stereo and audiophiles will scoff at it, it does produce surprisingly good sound. It\u2019s almost like they took some lessons from Bose in how to produce sound in a small device.I bought two a few weeks ago with the sale Amazing is have (44% off as of this review). If you want to replace an older generation Echo Dot (because you want better sound) or buy one for the first time, you can\u2019t go wrong with this generation.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on December 11, 2022
reviews: \nAs a former sonar technician for the United States Navy, I have to admit that the new motion sensors that these have included is the beez knees. It even uses the same kind of idea sensor array thati used to employ when I was busy singing to dolphins, I mean.. hunting submarines. \U0001f60f anyhow. I like it I love it and most of my new routines now revolve around the motion (or lack there of) thank you Amazon for kicking butt on that plus a who doesn\u2019t like the free Wi-Fi extension of the euro? I got the white one. I had the blue and the black for the fourth GEN but got the white one this round.  Amazon, way to go thank you thank you so much for this one. I appreciate you.Question though: WHAT IS THE RECOMMENDED HEIGHT AND PLACEMENT FOR THE 5th green echo dot to operate at peak performance for the motion sensing? I currently have my 4th Gen. about chest high, against a wall, standing in normal upright position. Would putting the butt end against the wall so the device is 90 degrees and the top where the buttons are is facing the room be a better way to utilize the sensing?Can I get access to aiming the arrays? I was trained by the navy to do it. :) just need access to the program.What do you say Amazon, can we talk? Either way. 5 star of course. Take my money!\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on October 22, 2022
titles: What can I say it\u2019s Alexa!
reviews: \nI have two original dots and thought about getting a new one . I was not sure this was going to be better and gave it a shot .I have the one with the mission battery base for the echo dot .I set this up and got it to work . I have the eero mesh system to connect it to . I then moved it and has to reset the internet on it and then it found the better eero to  connect with .This works good , I believe it is a much nicer sounding dot when comparing to the first generation . I like how you can move this around without loosing the power to it , just like the tap from years ago , just unplug the power cord and you have music on the go .I bought the blue dot and black base and comes with a white cord . Some people complain about the color not being black , I used a permanent black marker to color my cord , problem solved . Yes it should have come in black if ordering black .Hope this last for a long time like all the other devices I have .Would i recommend this , yes especially if you have the original one like me , I\u2019m just cheap and wanted something a little nicer and similar to the old tap .\n

titles: Bought this for smart switches and ended up using it for much more
reviews: \nI bought this to control the new smart switches i installed around the house and ended up using it for much more. After going through the setup and reading about all the features this dot has i now regularly use it to check the weather, traffic, and headlines before heading to work. i also find myself adding things to my shopping list as soon as i realize I've run out of something which has come on very handy. over all i though i would just use this to say  things like "alexa turn _____ lights on' but now i use it on a regular basis to multitask around the house while setting up plans for the week.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on October 24, 2022
titles: Much better sound than we expected
reviews: \nWe have over 20 Flexes, Inputs and Dots all over our house.  We also have a $8,000 HTD whole house wired music distribution system we installed over 10 years ago.  We find that unless we want to play at loud levels (which we virtually never do) the sound from our various Amazon devices all playing at the same time provides nearly the same quality of music as does our whole house system, so we made the decision to deprecated the HTD system and focus on improving the sound quality of our Amazon Echo/Dot system.  To that end we purchased 2 of these new 5th gen Dots to upgrade existing 2nd and third gen Dots.  For some time, we thought the Gen 3 dots were more than adequate as when tested side by side with the gen 2 dots there was an incredible improvement in sound.  We skipped the Gen 4 dot due to the numerous bad reviews on its sound quality and volume, but to be fair we never tested one.  In any case,  despite how impressed we were with the sound of the Gen 3, when played side by side with this new Gen 5, there is no comparison.  The 5 is amazingly better.  We had already replaced most of our gen 2 Dots with Gen 3s, and now we're likely to replace most of those with these new Gen 5s.  Expensive, but in the long run it will provide a very nice listening environment.We also have one of the Gen 4 Echos (not the Dot).  Being much larger in size and designed with music as a priority, the sound from the Gen 4 Premium Sound Echo is definitely better - more expansive, clearer, broader speaker responses, etc.  However, we've found that to only be true at higher volumes.  We don't use the Echo at those higher volumes and at moderate volumes, one has to listen fairly closely to hear an meaningful improvement over the 5th gen Dot.We will probably end up with 2 Gen 4 Premium Sound Echos and the most of the rest of our system will be Gen 5 Dots and keep only a few Gen 3 Dots where we don't really have a need for better sound.Overall, I think the Gen 5 Dot is a very good music delivery device.  We don't use the 3.5mm jack that was left off this new generation of Dot, and my wife notes that most walls are white so she prefers the white cord over the black that many wish Amazon would offer, at least with the black Dots.\n

reviews: \nThese smart hubs are easy to use, even the least tech savvy person could set it up and find benefit. The routines are slightly more difficult to navigate setup, however youtube videos or the help of anyone relatively knowledgeable with technology would suffice. (Routines are not necessary to find benefit with this product, but do add a level of satisfaction towards everyday living).Some devices that I have Alexa control: Sony Smart TV, Xbox Series X, smart outlets, smart bulbs, and more.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on February 21, 2023
reviews: \nI am completely satisfied with the item.  It does just what is described on the Amazon site.  The quality and workmanship is excellent.  I've bought several of these over the years and this is the best.  It has 2 new features that I haven't seen before:  1) It can sense when you walk into the room.  2) It can sense the room temperature.  This sounds much much better and clearer than the "hockey puck" echo variety.  (Better for voice as well as music.)\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on December 9, 2022
reviews: \nI've read many reviews & I almost didn't buy it. I'm old school & don't need a robot to shut off my TV or lights or make a grocery list for me. What I got this for was to tell Alexa to play my favorite types of music, ask the time, weather or ask about restaurants. That's it. I'm happy it does all of those perfectly. It was a bit frustrating to get it going from my phone. But, my husband got it done for me faster. The sound quality is nothing to rave about. I had it turned up with some pop music & it was just ok for me. I'm Gen X & most of us know about loud music and good quality sound. This has none of them. But overall it serves the purposes I got it for. I can shut my own lights off, tv etc. Hell I don't even want an electric car where the gov can shut off our cars if we don't do what they say in the future. I see to many ppl falling for these robots cause society today is lazy brained. Falling into the trap of the system. Wake up folks! Get up & physically do things YOURSELF!\n

reviews: \nIn general Echo lags just a bit behind Google Home in smartness but it more than makes up for it with response times, feature set and compatibility. I have more Echo devices than Google Home. Lights respond quicker when commanded via Echo. My wife has a physical disability and she uses Echo, among others, as a voice remote. She can select, navigate around the menu, play, pause, etc. on Fire TV via Echo. It is awesome. All my Christmas lights are connected to Echo. They used to be on normal manual timers, not anymore. Now I can have them on regular timers or even remotely turn them on/off. Echo is great for home automation.\n

titles: Experience Vibrant Sound in a Compact Design with the All-New Echo Dot (5th Gen, 2022 release)
reviews: \nI'm overjoyed with my Alexa speaker. It's small and sleek, enabling it to fit in any place in my house. The sound quality is excellent; it is far more vibrant and powerful than the previous generation.The Alexa integration is flawless; I can easily control my smart home devices, play music, and request information. I also like the new design of the light ring because it is more subtle and fits in with my decor.One feature that I really like is the ability to connect to other Echo devices, which allows me to play music throughout my entire house. I also like the extra privacy features, such as the ability to mute the microphone with a single button press.Overall, I'm very pleased with the All-New Echo Dot. It's a fantastic addition to my home, and I wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone in the market for a high-quality smart speaker. The sound quality and Alexa integration are excellent, and the design is sleek and fashionable.\n

\xa0She responds to my voice pretty good. My internet is slow sometimes, so I think that may interfere with her sometime. I've had this for a few days, and so far I am well pleased. No getting into my phone to Google things all the time or to set alarms and so forth. Now i don't know how she is on the integration. I'm not using this feature as of yet. I recommend. Giftable. This just makes life a little more easier when you are busy cleaning, cooking or just laying down resting and don't want to get into your phone to put music on , or you forgot to set the alarm. The set up was easy. After you place your order, you can set this up through your phone app and she will be ready out of the box. Just plug it in and wait for her to get ready. About a minute I would say. I unplug and re plug this in different rooms that I will be in for awhile. This had a little weight, but not heavy. I highly recommend. Giftable. Alexa was acting funny tonight through my phone. So I had a little problems getting her to respond from the echo dot and not through my phone.

reviews: \nAt first I thought that we would get minimal use for the device. We're not people that need to have music playing all day. But we find ourselves using it more and more often. It's easy to set up, easy to use, and the basic Prime music playlist is vast.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on January 2, 2023
reviews: \nI bought this for my aging parents for Christmas and was met by a less than enthusiastic reaction when they opened it.  After setting it up, answering a lot of questions about privacy and demonstrating some of the things it can do their attitudes changed to cautious curiosity.  As I write this review one day later I doubt I could pry this away from them if I tried!  They are loving it!Setup was very easy as long as you have a smartphone with the alexa app installed.  I did run into an initial wifi setup issue which was resolved simply by resetting the Alexa dot. Pairing the dot to 2 smart plugs was trivial and only took a couple of minutes.  Voice recognition was excellent even before running the customization routine.The sound on this device is outstanding!  One of the main reasons I bought it was so my mom could play music for my dad who has dementia. Quite frankly I was blown away by how good this thing sounds!  Think home theater quality...All in all I would highly recommend this Alexa dot!  If you are buying it for someone who is technology shy you will need to set it up for them and walk them through how to use it as the experience could be somewhat overwhelming otherwise.\n

This dot I'd also closest to the wifi extender.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on December 31, 2022
reviews: \nI recently purchased the Echo Dot and have been really impressed with it so far. As someone who isn't super tech-savvy, I was worried about setting it up and using all the features, but it was actually super easy and user-friendly.The voice control is definitely the standout feature for me. It's so convenient to be able to control my smart home devices and play music just by talking to the Echo Dot. And Alexa is pretty good at understanding what I'm saying, too. The sound quality is also really good for such a small speaker. I've been using it to listen to music and podcasts and it sounds great.I also really appreciate the sleek design of the Echo Dot. It's small and discreet, so it doesn't take up much space and fits in well with my home decor. The built-in speaker is a nice touch, too. I don't have a home phone, so it's been really handy to be able to make and receive calls with the Echo Dot.Overall, I'm really happy with my purchase. The Echo Dot is a great value for the price and has made my life a lot easier and more convenient. If you're thinking about getting a smart speaker, I'd definitely recommend giving the Echo Dot a try.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on January 6, 2023
titles: Much improved from the earlier versions
reviews: \nI started off with a hockey puck version at the location where I use this. I tried replacing it earlier with a prior version of this globe shaped one, which didn't work as well for me.This newer one has much better sound quality than either of the earlier ones. It has the added benefit of knowing the temperature. The limitation is that the Alexa app won't allow me to issue multiple separate commands in a routine. It will let you connect several with "and" but there's a low limit for the length of a command. So I couldn't have an Alexa routine that told me the temperatures in multiple places very well.It also adds Eero, which I don't use, but since the price didn't go up, it's nice to have something that might be handy in the future.\n

\xa0This little guy kicks! I was blown away how loud it can get. It does absolutely everything all the other Alexas do but a bit more compact. If you want it to be even louder you can Bluetooth it to another speaker. I love the routines and the Bluetooth light bulbs are a must for those. I have the lights come on in the living room when my alarm goes off in the morning. You can set the brightness so its not unpleasant. I also have her tell me the weather, and to have a great day, followed by my favorite radio station after I been up for 20 minutes. I love it and so will you.

titles: Very cool and speaker sound is superb
reviews: \nHonestly, I am at a loss. I am unsure how to best use Alexa, other than to play music, ask for the temperature, tell me terrible jokes, or just whisper to her to hear her whisper back.
